Promoting productive metathesis pathway and tuning activity of multidentate molybdenum catalysts in alkyne metathesis: A theoretical perspective Qiu-Hong Zhu Conceptualization Methodology Investigation Data curation Writing – original draft Writing – review & editing a Lei Zhang Methodology Investigation Data curation a Guo-Hao Zhang Methodology Investigation Data curation a Guo-Hong Tao Supervision Project administration Funding acquisition a Song Qin Methodology a Hao Chen Resources Investigation a Wen-Li Yuan Investigation Data curation a Yuan-Hao Wang Methodology Data curation a Yinghua Jin Methodology Writing – review & editing b Lijian Ma Supervision a Ling He Conceptualization Supervision Writing – review & editing Project administration Funding acquisition a ⁎ Wei Zhang Conceptualization Supervision Writing – review & editing Project administration b ⁎ a College of Chemistry, Sichuan University, Chengdu 610064, China College of Chemistry Sichuan University Chengdu 610064 China aCollege of Chemistry, Sichuan University, Chengdu 610064, China b Department of Chemistry, University of Colorado Boulder, Boulder, CO 80309, USA Department of Chemistry University of Colorado Boulder Boulder CO 80309 USA bDepartment of Chemistry, University of Colorado Boulder, Boulder, CO 80309, USA ⁎ Corresponding authors. Molybdenum alkylidyne complexes, including those containing monodentate or multidentate ligands, can catalyze CC bond formation via alkyne metathesis, which is of great importance to organic synthesis and materials chemistry. Herein, to understand the catalyst working mechanism and explore the key parameters determining the catalyst performance, alkyne metathesis catalyzed by molybdenum-based multidentate complexes was systematically investigated using density functional theory calculations. By comparing the desired cross metathesis and undesired polymerization pathways in multidentate and monodentate catalytic systems, the former shows significantly higher activation barrier for alkyne polymerization, resulting in the shutdown of ring-expansion by-product formation. Furthermore, the calculations show that the multidentate ligands taking trigonal-pyramidal geometry play two roles: (1) occupying one of substrate coordination sites to inhibit the polymerization pathway, thus promoting the desired productive pathway; (2) changing the electronic and steric environment to tune catalytic activity. It is worth noting that the metallacyclobutadiene complex with hither plane feature may play a key role in determining the activity of the catalysts. This work thus provides a guiding principle toward high-performance multidentate catalysts for alkyne metathesis. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract By comparing the productive cross metathesis and undesired polymerization pathways in alkyne metathesis, the multidentate molybdenum-based catalyst dramatically raise the activation energy barrier for alkyne polymerization, thus shutting down the side reaction pathway. Both electronic and steric environment strongly influenced by the ligand central group are responsible for the activity of the multidentate catalysts. Keywords Alkyne metathesis Molybdenum carbyne Catalysts Multidentate ligand Density functional theory Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Since its discovery in 1968 [1], alkyne metathesis has emerged as an invaluable synthetic tool in organic chemistry and material science. Alkyne metathesis is a dynamic exchange reaction, which enables the expedient and convergent construction of motifs with alkynyl linkage through the breaking and formation of CC triple bond [2–6]. Recently, alkyne metathesis has been applied in the synthesis of natural products [7–9], organic molecular cages [10–16], and polymers [17–25]. In alkyne metathesis, the nonproductive pathway must be considered: polymerization of small alkyne substrates, in particular 2-butyne, is prone to form metallacycle by-products via ring expansion pathway (Scheme 1 ) [26]. Schrock pioneered the development of metathetical reactions of acetylenes on a homogeneous high oxidation state d0 metal catalysts, known as Schrock-type alkylidyne complexes [27,28]. The various Schrock-type catalysts based on monodentate ligands were reported and exhibited remarkable reactivity and broader substrate scope [29–42]. Very recently, a d2Re(V)-based catalyst bearing the PO-chelating ligands and a pyridine ligand was also reported, which is air and moisture stable, and active for various substrates at high temperature under nitrogen [43]. In the mechanism for alkyne metathesis, the metal alkylidyne complex and an alkyne substrate undergoes a [2 + 2] cycloaddition step to give a metallacyclobutadiene intermediate (Scheme 2 a) [44,45]. The intermediate can either undergo cycloaddition to produce cyclic compounds or cycloreversion to release the desired products by computational methods [46,47]. Theoretical and experimental studies indicated that the activity and reaction selectivity for alkyne metathesis can be tuned by modifying the catalyst ligands [48–51]. Within the past ten years or so, we have designed and developed a series of multidentate ligand-based molybdenum (Mo) catalysts, with a trigonal-pyramidal geometry shown in Scheme 2c [52–56]. These multidentate catalysts can completely shut down the undesired polymerization pathway, exhibit high alkyne metathesis activity as well as broad substrate scope, even for many challenging substrates containing nitro and aldehyde functional groups. A class of multidentate-based catalysts efficiently used in open air for alkyne metathesis was also reported recently [57]. We have clearly demonstrated the advantages of multidentate catalysts employed to synthesize well-defined discreet molecular architectures via alkyne metathesis [58–61]. Recently, Hillenbrand et al. independently reported an unconventional molybdenum alkylidyne catalyst with tripodal silanolate ligands, which shows excellent functional group tolerance [62–64]. For these catalysts with multidentate ligands feature, no any undesired polymerization by-products were observed in metathesis of alkyne [53]. Although these multidentate catalysts have exhibited superior performance in alkyne metathesis, their working mechanism and the rationale for their great performance from a theoretical point of view has rarely been reported. Moreover, the further improvement of catalytic activity of multidentate complexes (e.g., longer life time, higher resistivity to moisture, broader substrate scope, etc.) through rational design is highly desired. The accurate theoretical calculation has been proven to be a critical tool for the rational design of effective metal-ligand catalysts [65]. Herein, using density functional theory (DFT) methods, we elucidate the mechanism of Mo catalysts containing multidentate ligands for alkyne metathesis, and further verify its high cross metathesis selectivity by comparing monodentate and multidentate catalytic system. The DFT calculation is based on the energy barrier of transition states from a selected model reaction to evaluate the catalytic performance of complexes. Subsequent studies on electron-controlling factors, such as substituents and central atoms linking ligands on multidentate catalysts, resulted in a predictable metathesis activity. Additional steric effect around Mo in complexes for substrate association was further studied. The results show that the central atoms bonded with multiple binding sites forming a rigid multidentate structure can tune the steric hindrance of complexes, thus influencing their catalytic activity. 2 Computational details All of the density functional theory calculations were performed by the Gaussian09 suites of programs [66] in this work. The full geometry optimization of all structures and transition states (TSs) has been carried out at the DFT level of theory using the B3LYP functional combined with Grimme's D3(BJ) method [67–69]. The geometry optimization was performed by using a relativistic Stuttgart pseudo-potential, with the Stuttgart/Dresden (SDD) valence basis set to describe Mo, and the 6-31G(d, p) basis set to describe C, N, O, Si, and H atoms [70]. Vibrational frequency calculations of the optimized structures were simulated at the same level of theory to verify that the stationary points were the local minima on the potential energy surface without imaginary frequency, or TSs with one imaginary frequency. Intrinsic reaction coordinate (IRC) calculations [71] were also performed in geometrical optimizations to confirm the true TSs connecting the reactants and products. The single point calculations on the optimized geometries were performed to further refine the electronic energies. The SDD basis set for Mo and 6-311+G(2d,2p) basis set for nonmetal atoms including zero-point vibrational energy corrections (ZPEs) was employed to calculate single-point energies. Furthermore, Grimme's DFT-D3(BJ) correction and solvent effect by a self-consistent reaction field (SCRF) were considered, where the PCM solvent model was used with carbon tetrachloride solvent (CCl4, dielectric constant ε = 2.2280) as solvent. The temperature of 313 K (for experimental temperature at 40 °C) correction was included in the optimization procedure. The corrected Gibbs free energies (G) were determined by adding thermochemical corrections of the geometries to electronic energies. The natural bonding orbitals (NBOs) [72,73], molecular orbitals (MOs) [74], electrostatic potentials (ESPs) [75,76], and noncovalent interaction (NCI) [77] were calculated at the B3LYP-D3(BJ)/6-311+G(2d,2p) (SDD for Mo) level. 3 Results and discussion The reaction mechanism composed of the following two processes in general: (1) the cycloaddition of catalyst with alkyne substrate; (2) the cycloreversion of metallacyclobutadiene intermediate to release product and second alkylidyne. In the second step, there is a competitive by-product pathway of ring expansion. 3.1 Selectivity in productive pathway of multidentate Mo catalyst in alkynes metathesis Our discussion starts by analyzing the potential energy profiles for 2a catalytic system consisting of the multidentate phenolic ligand. 2-Butyne was employed as a model substrate because it provides a simple computing task. For catalyst 2a, the key features are three 2-hydroxybenzyl-5-nitro moieties bonded by central N atom, and the three phenolic oxygens coordinated with Mo to give a trigonal-pyramidal geometry (Scheme 2c). As illustrated in Fig. 1 a, in the metathesis pathway of catalyst 2a, the complex first undergoes a cycloaddition step via electrophilic attacking on the 2-butyne (step 1) to generate a metallacyclobutadiene intermediate 2a-IM1. The MoC triple bond of the catalyst was deemed as the operative unit in a formal [2 + 2] cycloaddition. Step 1 occurs via the transition state 2a-TS1, and has an energy barrier (ΔΔG≠) of 7.2 kcal mol−1. Further process of the reaction is 2a-IM1 undergoes a cycloreversion step (red line in step 2) via 2a-TS2, with the energy barrier (ΔΔG≠) of 3.3 kcal mol−1 relative to 2a-IM1. Thereby producing the desired product and regenerating a competent catalyst entity. Then proceed the same steps to complete the turnover. The results are in good agreement with the experimental observation that the alkyne metathesis catalyzed by multidentate catalyst 2a proceeds under mild conditions [53]. To elucidate the experimentally observed cross metathesis selectivity in multidentate catalytic system, detailed investigations of the possible polymerization pathway for 2-butyne substrates in the presence of catalyst 2a were performed by using the same computational protocol. The catalytic system 1 containing similar phenolic ligand, where the three p-nitrophenol ligands were monodentate bonded with Mo center, was also calculated. The potential energy profiles were provided in Fig. 1b. It clearly shows the polymerization of 2-butyne substrates is much more challenging to occur for multidentate catalyst 2a than for monodentate catalyst 1. As shown in the black pathway of step 2 in Fig. 1a, further reaction for intermediate IM1 with another 2-butyne molecule leads to the polymerized intermediate IM2 via a six-membered ring transition state TS2. A relatively high free energy (ΔG) of 20.6 kcal mol−1 via 2a-TS2a was observed in catalyst 2a, with a barrier of 16.2 kcal mol−1 relative to 2a-IM1. This implies that compared to cycloreversion, the ring expansion reaction are challenging to occur. For actual reaction substrate p-chlorophenyl propargyne (Figs. S2 and S4), the calculated energy barrier of six-membered ring TS was dramatically high (ΔΔG≠ = 26.7 kcal mol−1), consistent with the experimental findings that no any polymerization products were found in catalyst 2a. The ΔΔG≠ relative to 2a-IMI2 for cycloreversion via 2a-TSI2 was 10.6 kcal mol−1. However, in monodentate catalytic system, the ΔΔG≠ for the formation of the six-membered ring intermediate via 1-TS2b was 18.4 kcal mol−1, for cycloreversion step via 1-TS2 was 14.1 kcal mol−1, relative to 1-IM1. For p-chlorophenyl propargyne substrate (Figs. S3 and S4), the relatively barrier for metathesis and polymerization pathway through 1-TSI2 and 1-TSI2b were 9.5 and 13.5 kcal mol−1. This means that the metathesis selectivity of monodentate catalyst 1 is lower than multidentate catalyst 2a. The energy profile with the p-(1-propynyl)benzaldehyde as substrate and 2a as catalyst was provided in Fig. S5. The optimized TS structures for the four- and six-membered ring are shown in Fig. 2 a. Natural bond orbital (NBO) analysis was carried out to reveal the inertness of nonproductive polymerization for multidentate catalyst, as illustrated in Fig. 2b. According to the analysis of unfilled LP* p-type orbital for Mo metal, the monodentate catalyst 1 possesses two open sites for the substrate binding. However, for multidentate system, the rigid structure feature results in the blocking of one substrate binding site (Fig. 2a). After the catalyst and 2-butyne form a four-member ring intermediate, the intermediate 1-IM1 can easily react with another small molecule substrate through the ring-expansion mechanism to initiate polymerization. By contrast, there is a clear steric effect in 2a-IM1 intermediate, inhibiting the polymerization pathway. Fig. 2c showed the optimized structures and corresponding molecular orbitals (MOs) interaction diagram for the six-membered ring intermediate IM2 in both multidentate and monodentate systems. The 2-butyne and four-membered ring intermediate IM1 are, respectively, taken as the two fragments of IM2. It is found that the orbital contribution of 2-butyne molecule toward intermediate IM2 in 2a system is much less than that in 1 system. The highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) of IM2 is directly derived from the HOMO of 2-butyne and IM1, with the contribution of 15% and 43% in 2a-based system, and 22% and 23% in 1-based system, respectively, (red curves in Fig. 2c). The 11% and 14% contribution values from the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) of 2-butyne to IM2 were observed in both systems, as highlighted by the blue curves in Fig. 2c. More orbital information was supplied in Fig. S6. Extended charge decomposition analysis (ECDA) results illustrate that the number of net electrons transferring from 2-butyne toward 2a-IM2 was 0.0354, and toward 1-IM2 was 0.0571. In short, the MOs analyses clearly showed that the monodentate catalytic system provides a more stable six-membered ring intermediate. As a result, the monodentate complex greatly facilitates the ring expansion pathway than the multidentate coordination mode. 3.2 Activity of multidentate Mo catalyst in alkyne metathesis From the above calculations, in contrast to monodentate co-ligands system, the nonproductive substrate binding is greatly minimized in catalyst with multidentate ligand, which is beneficial to the desired cross metathesis. In the following sections, we investigated the catalytic activity of multidentate complexes for alkyne metathesis by changing the center atom of multidentate ligands. A notable feature of the catalyst with multidentate ligand is the central N atom of trigonal-pyramidal geometry, which occupies one coordination site of Mo, resulting in great metathesis selectivity. However, experimentally, the complex with central N coordinating ligand reduces its catalytic activity [52,54]. So, the question is: How to effectively improve the catalytic activity of multidentate complex? It is clear that the substituted electron-withdrawing group is responsible for the catalytic activity in alkyne metathesis. The catalysts containing substituted nitro group (2a), hydrogen group (2b), and hydroxyl group (2c) were computed and compared (Scheme 2d). As can be readily seen in Table 1 and Fig. S7, lower barrier was found for the formation of four-membered ring in 2a system (ΔΔG≠ = 7.2 kcal mol−1) than 2b (ΔΔG≠ = 10.6 kcal mol−1) and 2c system (ΔΔG≠ = 10.6 kcal mol−1), which is due to the fact that catalyst 2a feature lower LUMO energy. The LUMO of −2.91, −1.53, and −1.33 eV for 2a, 2b, and 2c system were calculated, respectively. The lower LUMO energy interacts more strongly with the HOMO of 2-butyne molecule (about −0.240 a.u., −6.54 eV). Fig. 3 showed the electrostatic potential (ESP) vdW surface of complexes. The patterns of distribution of the ESP in catalytic systems 2a, 3a, and 4b were quite similar. However, very different ESP surface values were observed, especially the region of charge around Mo. Compared to the 2a system (+3.77 kcal mol−1), more electrophilic Mo areas with higher ESP surfaces of +4.98 and +4.63 kcal mol−1 were observed for 3a and 4b catalysts. These electrophilicity (3a > 4b > 2a) is roughly consistent with the order of their activation barriers (2.3, 3.9, 7.1 kcal mol−1 for 4b, 3a and 2a, respectively, Table 2 and Fig. S9). The exhibited negative charge region around Mo in catalysts 2b and 2c also indicated their low electrophilicity and activity (Figs. S10 and S11). In addition to electronic effect, another important role of central atom is to tune the steric environment where substrate attacks. Noncovalent interaction (NCI) analyses were performed to estimate the steric clash of 2-butyne attack in 2a, 3a, and 4b systems. As shown in Fig. S12, there is a clear steric repulsion between the MoC bond of all complexes and the CC bond of 2-butyne in transition state TS1. However, the sign(λ2)ρ of positive spike is obviously different (in red circle of Fig. S12), which is a key approach to investigate steric effect. The spikes were observed at 0.0339, 0.0198, and 0.0286 in 2a, 3a, and 4b systems, respectively. Larger sign(λ2)ρ value corresponds to stronger steric repulsion in transition state. The steric repulsion order (3a < 4b < 2a) reveals the increase of their activation barriers. Fig. 4 showed the dihedral angle values between CMoC and MoCO in catalysts, which allows an assessment of the potential resistance of the substrate to attack the Mo in the catalyst. A significantly larger dihedral angle was found in the 3a catalyst (about 103.6°) than that of 2a (about 88.7°) and 4b (about 81.7°). The “distortion” of ligand in 3a catalyst is also less than that in other systems. The above results drive us to think about the importance of the potential steric effect. Calculations of catalysts 4a were also performed (Fig. S13), the free energy profile is shown in Fig. S14. The first cycloaddition step is endergonic by only 2.3 kcal mol−1 when the Si-H group is same “upward” oriented conformer as 3a, which was 1.6 kcal mol−1 lower than that of 3a-TS1. Such low energy barrier of 4a suggests that more expanded “cage ligand structure” corresponds to more open space for the access of substrate, thus resulting in higher reactivity. The barrier of 17.9 kcal mol−1 was obtained as the Si-H group of 4a is “downward” oriented (Fig. S14). This may be attributed to its smaller space in which the substrate attacks from the equator. The “downward” oriented isomer is more stable than “upward” oriented. Overall, our calculation results suggested that the central link sites of ligands in Mo catalysts serve two functions in promoting the metathesis pathway. (1) The sites promote productive cross metathesis pathway for alkyne. Compared to monodentate catalytic system, the central group connecting ligands in multidentate system occupies one of substrate binding sites of Mo to form a trigonal-pyramidal geometry. Such structure feature exhibits more favorable metathesis selectivity for alkyne. (2) The sites tune the activity of complex (based on the ligands with electron-withdrawing substituents). Other than the increased catalytic activity of electron-withdrawing substituents in ligands in multidentate catalysts, the central group in multidentate ligands can further adjust the activation barriers in initial Mo-alkyne association step. Both electronic and steric effects are strongly influenced by the central group. 3.3 Alkyne metathesis catalyzed by multidentate Mo complex 5 Recently, we reported a class of multidentate Mo catalysts without methylene tethers in the ligand (catalyst 5) [57], as shown in Scheme 2d. To check the validity of the above DFT predictions, we investigated the energy profiles of catalyst 5a and 5b under the same level. The first cycloaddition step, through 5a-TS1, has an energy barrier of 1.7 kcal mol−1 relative to 5b-COM1, which is lower than other catalysts (2a, 3a, 4b) containing extra methylene tethers in the ligands (Table 3 and Fig. S15). In catalyst 5b, the barrier relative to 5b-COM1 for the formation of four-membered ring intermediate, via 5b-TS1, was 2.0 kcal mol−1. This is consistent with empirical data, since excellent activity and yield were observed. The LUMO energy of catalyst 5a and 5b were −3.11 and −2.89 eV, and the dihedral angle value were 91.6° and 91.16°, respectively. Different from catalyst 3a, 5 systems are not hindered by the -CH2 groups when it is bound with the substrate (Fig. 5 a). This means that potential steric hindrance of system 5 is smaller than those catalysts containing extra methylene tethers in the ligands, thus resulting in a lower energy barrier (Fig. S16). As illustrated in Fig. S17, a small positive spike of 0.0189 in NCI analysis of 5a verified our speculation. Notably, the four-membered ring intermediate 3b-IM1 in catalyst 3b is not planar, with the C3 group is tilted 30.4° out of the M−C1−C2 plane (Fig. 5b), which is considered to have constraints for [2 + 2] cycloreversion55. However, for catalyst 5, the C3 is only slightly tilted out of the M−C1−C2 plane (less than 5°), and it is fairly close to a planar conformation. This feature could favor the formation and cleavage of metallacyclobutadiene in alkyne metathesis. Additional DFT calculations were performed to study the alkyne metathesis pathway using the p-(1-propynyl) benzaldehyde as the substrate (instead of 2-butyne), where the complex 5b was employed as catalyst. As shown in Fig. 5c, the barrier of the first four-membered ring formation is favored through 5b-TSI1 (ΔΔG≠ = 2.0 kcal mol−1 relative to 5b-COMI1), generating intermediate 5b-IMI1. The complex 5b-COMI2 is then readily formed by the cycloreversion of 5b-IMI2, through 5b-TSI2 with a ΔΔG≠ of 10.2 kcal mol−1 relative to 5b-IMI2. Another substrate attacks to form a less stable reactant complex 5b-COMI3 with a free energy of −1.1 kcal mol−1, and then forms the second four-membered ring intermediate via 5b-TSI3 (ΔΔG≠ = 1.6 kcal mol−1 relative to 5b-COMI3). The optimized structures of alkynes complexes COMI1, COMI2 and COMI3 were shown in Fig. S18. From intermediate 5b-IMI4, metathesis product can obtain readily via 5b-TSI4. The barrier relative to 5b-IMI4 was 9.6 kcal mol−1. The alkyne polymerization pathway using the p-(1-propynyl)benzaldehyde as the substrate and 5b as catalyst was also calculated. Fig. S19 illustrates that the ΔG of another substrate molecular attacking the metallacyclobutadiene intermediate (5b-IMI1) to undergo the polymerization path was 8.4 kcal mol−1 via 5b-TSI2b. The ΔΔG≠ between intermediate and TS was 23.6 kcal mol−1, which is higher than the barrier of cycloreversion (14.0 kcal mol−1). Above results indicate that the catalyst 5 has a low free energy barrier, consistent with the experimentally observed 3% catalyst loading in 1.5 h to achieve 94% yield. 4 Conclusion In summary, we systematically studied the alkyne metathesis reaction catalyzed by Mo-catalysts containing multidentate ligands using DFT calculations for the first time. The results show that the alkyne binding ability of Mo alkylidyne catalysts determines the energy barrier of transition states via cycloaddition and cycloreversion steps. By comparing multidentate and monodentate catalysts, the former exhibit significantly higher barrier for nonproductive pathway, thus shutting down the formation of polymer by-products through ring expansion pathway. The multidentate catalysts possess a trigonal-pyramidal geometry feature, which is composed of a central group connecting each binding site and Mo metal. The central group blocks one of the coordinating sites of Mo, which leads to great cross metathesis selectivity of the catalysts. In addition to improving the selectivity mentioned above, the central group in the multidentate catalysts is also important to the catalytic activity. The calculations indicate that the central group is responsible for both the electronic structure and steric clash around Mo in complexes, consequently influencing their activation barriers. We found that a smaller steric hindrance of catalysts for substrate attack could enable higher activity. This study provides useful guidelines in the design of superior multidentate Mo catalysts in alkyne metathesis. coredata.dc:description: Molybdenum alkylidyne complexes, including those containing monodentate or multidentate ligands, can catalyze CC bond formation via alkyne metathesis, which is of great importance to organic synthesis and materials chemistry. Herein, to understand the catalyst working mechanism and explore the key parameters determining the catalyst performance, alkyne metathesis catalyzed by molybdenum-based multidentate complexes was systematically investigated using density functional theory calculations. By comparing the desired cross metathesis and undesired polymerization pathways in multidentate and monodentate catalytic systems, the former shows significantly higher activation barrier for alkyne polymerization, resulting in the shutdown of ring-expansion by-product formation. Furthermore, the calculations show that the multidentate ligands taking trigonal-pyramidal geometry play two roles: (1) occupying one of substrate coordination sites to inhibit the polymerization pathway, thus promoting the desired productive pathway; (2) changing the electronic and steric environment to tune catalytic activity. It is worth noting that the metallacyclobutadiene complex with hither plane feature may play a key role in determining the activity of the catalysts. This work thus provides a guiding principle toward high-performance multidentate catalysts for alkyne metathesis.
coredata.dc:title: Promoting productive metathesis pathway and tuning activity of multidentate molybdenum catalysts in alkyne metathesis: A theoretical perspective
